message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and examination findings suggest polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Bilateral adnexal masses indicate the presence of ovarian cysts, which are a common feature of PCOS. The most appropriate next step in management is monitoring, as the patient is pregnant and surgical intervention carries risks. Diagnostic laparoscopy and oophorectomy should only be considered if the masses continue to grow or cause complications. Measurement of serum CEA is not relevant in this case, as CEA is a tumor marker used to detect cancers, and there is no indication of cancer in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and examination results suggest a possible diagnosis of ovarian hyperthecosis or a virilizing ovarian tumor. However, with a viable pregnancy, surgical intervention is risky. Monitoring the patient closely with ultrasonography and serum testosterone levels is the best next step in management. Option A or B may be considered after delivery of the baby. Option D, measurement of serum CEA, is not indicated in this case as it is a marker for cancer, not ovarian hyperthecosis or a virilizing tumor.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest the patient has ovarian hyperthecosis. While surgical removal of the masses may be necessary, management at this point should focus on monitoring the patient and the growth of the mass. Diagnostic laparoscopy is not indicated at this point. Measurement of serum CEA is not indicated as it is not associated with ovarian hyperthecosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the presence of bilateral ovarian masses with increased serum androgen levels suggest the diagnosis of ovarian hyperthecosis. As the patient is pregnant, surgical options should be avoided unless necessary. Monitoring the patient closely with repeat ultrasonography and serum androgen level measurements is the most appropriate next step in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest the patient has a case of ovarian hyperandrogenism and the bilateral adnexal masses on palpation indicate ovarian tumors. Since the pregnancy is live and the ultrasound shows no other problems, the most appropriate next step in management would be monitoring. Surgery or diagnostic laparoscopy can be considered after delivery if the tumors grow rapidly or if the patient has any cancer markers. Serum CEA is not commonly elevated in ovarian tumors, and unlikely to help in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and examination findings suggest ovarian tumors, and monitoring is the most appropriate next step in management. Diagnostic laparoscopy or oophorectomy may be considered if the tumors continue to grow or if symptoms worsen. Measurement of serum CEA is not relevant in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest ovarian hyperstimulation, which can occur during pregnancy. The most appropriate next step in management would be monitoring, as surgical interventions carry risks for the mother and fetus. A biopsy of the masses can be performed if there is concern for malignancy, but measurement of serum CEA is not relevant in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests a diagnosis of ovarian hyperandrogenism, which is often managed conservatively with close monitoring. Diagnostic laparoscopy and oophorectomy may be indicated in certain cases, but monitoring is the most appropriate initial step. Measurement of serum CEA is not relevant to this presentation as it is a tumor marker for colorectal cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is exhibiting symptoms of ovarian hyperandrogenism, which could be caused by benign bilateral ovarian masses. Monitoring is the most appropriate next step in management because surgical intervention may pose a risk to the ongoing pregnancy. Diagnostic laparoscopy and oophorectomy are not recommended during pregnancy unless there is an emergent need. Serum CEA is not relevant to this presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and examination findings suggest polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), and the ultrasonography findings suggest bilateral ovarian masses. Diagnostic laparoscopy and oophorectomy may be required in some cases, but in this situation with a 28-week gestation, monitoring is the most appropriate next step. Measurement of serum CEA would not be useful in this scenario.
